journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: The weak fault diagnosis and condition monitoring of rolling element bearing using minimum entropy deconvolution and envelop spectrum

article-meta.aff: 1State Key Laboratory of Mechanical System and Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China
2Shanghai Institute of Satellite Engineering, Shanghai, China

author-notes.corresp: Ruilong Jiang, State Key Laboratory of Mechanical System and Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, 800 Dongchuan Road, Shanghai 200240, China. Email: jiangrlsjtu@gmail.com

abstract.p: In vibration analysis, weak fault detect and diagnosis is of great importance. A method based on minimum entropy deconvolution and envelop spectrum analysis is proposed in this article. Minimum entropy deconvolution technique searches for an optimal set of filter coefficients to enhance the impulse making the filtered signal to contain clearer fault information. When there is a fault in bearing, it can be obviously reflected by the power spectral density estimation of the filtered signal even if the power spectral density estimation of original signal denies the information. The filtered signals are then analyzed by performing envelop spectrum analysis, where the bearing characteristic frequencies are quite clear for further diagnosis. The feasibility and validity of utilizing the minimum entropy deconvolution in weak fault diagnosis and condition monitoring is demonstrated by both simulation and experiments. The analysis of actual data from accelerated life test of rolling bearing shows that it can detect and diagnose fault 7 min earlier than RMS can reflect while the entire life takes 1962 min. This is considered to be significant in condition monitoring and early incipient fault diagnosis. The results of gearbox test also demonstrates the effective bearing fault diagnosis under strong noise and gear vibration interactions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Rolling element bearings are one of the most widely used element in rotary machine, and they also play a pivotal role in the whole system. Failure of bearings in industrial machines and other vital equipments may result in financial loss even claiming lives. Therefore, fault diagnostic and condition monitoring based on the analysis of vibration signals have gained a lot of attention and has been of great significance.

The key issue of fault diagnostic lies in identifying the potential faults inside an operating machine accurately. However, it is not an easy task to extract the representative features from the original signal when the fault information is corrupted by strong background noise, or when the fault is weak at an early stage.1 Many researches have been done over these years, and some very powerful diagnostic techniques are now available for weak fault detection.2,3 Wavelet analysis is widely used for detecting local faults in bearings by many researchers.4 Many approaches propose combining wavelet analysis with neutral network or hidden Markov model for better diagnosis of incipient faults.5 Spectral kurtosis (SK) is another useful tool, which provides a robust way of detecting weak fault in rotation even in the presence of strong masking noise.6 In this regard, significant work has been done by Antoni and Randoll.7,8 Cyclostationarity provides powerful tools for analyzing vibration signals captured on rotating machinery for fault diagnosis.9 Ming et al.10 extracted the weak fault feature with cyclic Wiener filter, and it worked well with the actual data from bearing accelerated life test.

The minimum entropy deconvolution (MED) method is designed to reduce the spread of impulse response frequencies, to obtain signals closer to the original impulses that give rise to them.11 It has been successfully used in the fields of seismic signal processing, ultrasonic inspection of composite materials and pipes.12,13 Endo and Randall14 detected gear tooth fault use MED filter to enhance impulse of autoregressive (AR) filter residual signal. Sawalhi et al.15 took advantage of MED combined with SK to enhance the fault detection and diagnosis in rolling bearing. MED actually is a very powerful technique for impulse enhancement, which means it has a lot of potential in weak fault detection and diagnosis.

Typically, when fault occurs in the rolling element bearings, impulse occurs due to the impact of two contact surfaces, and this excites the resonances of the structure making the vibration signals exhibit the feature of amplitude modulation.16 This can be reflected by the power spectral density (PSD) estimation. Envelop analysis is a widely used method to separate modulating signal from the carrier signal, which typically contains information that indicates the faults.17,18

In this article, a method for weak fault diagnosis using MED and envelop analysis is explored. MED filter is applied to the original signal to enhance the impulse. When there is a fault in bearing, it can be obviously reflected by the PSD estimation of the outcome of MED filter even if the PSD estimation of original signal denies the information. And then the envelop spectrum based on Hilbert transform is calculated. In the envelop spectrum, the bearing characteristic frequencies are quite clear for further diagnosis.

This article is organized as follows. In the following, an introduction about the rolling element bearing and vibration signature of bearing faults is provided. The later sections are dedicated to MED and envelop spectrum analysis. Simulated data with signal to noise ratio (SNR) of −12 dB is used to illustrate the validity of the proposed method. ‘Experiment results validation’ section includes the experimental data, processing results of two cases. In case I, accelerated life test of rolling bearing is performed to collect data over the entire lifetime (normal fault failure). The proposed method is used to detect and diagnose the incipient fault much earlier than RMS can reflect. In case II, a single-stage gearbox test is performed to collect experimental data. The proposed method is used to detect and diagnose the bearing fault under strong noise. The conclusion is made in the final section.

sec.title: Rolling element bearing introduction
sec.p:
Rolling element, which transfers the main load through elements in rolling contact rather than sliding contact, is made up of four parts: the outer race, the inner race, the rolling element, and the cage. Due to the difference between roller bearing and ball bearing, this article focuses on ball bearing only. The structure and the main load distribution is shown in Figure 1. Assuming there is only pure rolling contact between the rolling element and the raceway (the inner and outer race), the possible fault is normally expressed as localized single point defect. According to the location of the defects, the bearing faults can be simply categorized into outer race defects, inner race defects, ball defects, and cage defects. Typically, when fault occurs in a bearing, the vibration signals present the feature of amplitude modulation.16,19 The measured vibration signal contains a harmonic series with one of four characteristic frequencies depending on the location of defects. The four characteristic frequencies are shown as follows20 (1)Ball defects:fb=(fr/2DbDp)(Dp2-(Dbcosθ)2)Inner race defects:fi=(Nbfr/2Dp)(Dp+Dbcosθ)Outer race defects:fo=(Nbfr/2Dp)(Dp-Dbcosθ)Cage defects:fc=(fr/2Dp)(Dp-Dbcosθ) where Dp and Db are pitch diameter and ball diameter respectively, θ is the ball contact angle with races, Nb is the number of rolling element (ball), and fr is the shaft rotational frequency. Figure 1.
Rolling element bearing’s structure and load distribution.

sec.title: Bearing fault model
sec.p: The vibration of rolling element bearing under the defect state, which is mainly affected by geometry shape, tolerance, shaft speed, load distribution, defect type, transfer function and so on, is turned out to be complex and very difficult to be described by models. The theoretical foundation of bearing failure modes has been researched for decades, and some successful models have been developed by many researchers.16,19 As introduced in the previous section ‘Rolling element bearing introduction’, the vibration signals present the feature of amplitude modulation. What’s more, previous research shows that vibration signal reveal pseudo-cyclostationary nature due to the random slip between rolling element and the cage.21 A model, proposed by Macfadden, is proved to be very effective in dealing with single point defect and can be extended to characterize multiple point defects. The model is expressed as follows (2){x(t)=∑k=1MAks(t-kT-τk)+n(t)Ak=A0cos(2πQt+ϕA)+CAs(t)=e-Btsin(2πfnt+ϕw) where Ak is the kth amplitude, which modulates with period 1/Q(Q=1/fr), s(t) is the attenuated damping oscillation, which is affected by mean impulse period between two adjacent shocks (T), the time lag of period T at the kth impact caused by slip (τk), and the white noise n(t). CA is the arbitrary constant, A0 is the amplitude of modulating signal, which corresponds to the load under the bearing, B is the resonance damping coefficient depending on system, and fn is the natural frequency of system.

sec.title: Power spectrum density estimation
sec.p: As introduced in the previous sections, with the existence of defect the impact between the rolling element and raceway will excite the bearing natural frequency, and the characteristic frequency is modulated as series of harmonic. Typically, the bearing nature frequency is normally larger than 2 kHz, so this can be reflected by the PSD estimation. Experimental data from Case Western Reserve University is used to investigate the effective of PSD estimation.22 Three single point defects with three degrees of severity are introduced separately and the data are collected at three different loads. These faults are processed by electrical discharge machining (EDM) with defect diameters of 0.007, 0.014, and 0.021 in. The sampling rate is set to12 kHz.

Since the defect is more prone to occur in the inner race rather than at the outer race or rolling element, we select the data of inner race fault bearings with defect diameter of 0.007, 0.0014, and 0.021 in. and the load of 2 horsepower. The data of the normal bearing in the same load is also analyzed. PSD estimation during normal operation and inner defect of three degrees severity are calculated. The results are shown as Figure 2. Figure 2.
Power spectral density estimation during normal operation and inner defect of three degrees severity.

It is clear from Figure 2 that during normal operation with no defects the energy is concentrated in the area lower than 2 kHz. With the presence of defect, the energy gives rise to sidebands with most energy between 2 and 4 kHz. The proportion of energy between 2 and 4 kHz increase with the defect diameter. In other words, it is more obvious to detect the energy more than 2 kHz since the degradation of the bearing. When the condition becomes serious, in which the bearing defect diameter is 0.021 in., there is almost no existence of lower frequency energy. This can be used in bearing condition monitoring. In order to identify the defect type, further analysis such as envelop spectrum analysis is needed, and this will be introduced in the ‘Envelop spectrum analysis’ section.

sec.title: Minimum entropy deconvolution
sec.p: Information entropy was firstly presented by Shannon to measure information’s uncertainty.23 When information becomes more Gaussian, or more disorder, entropy will become higher. In recent years, information entropy is widely used as a characteristic index of fault diagnosis on engineering.24 The MED technique was first proposed by Wiggins, and has been successfully used in dealing the seismic response signal. Further meaningful works have been done by many other researchers, such as the relationship between MED and independent component analysis (ICA),25 the design of MED filter using objective function method (OFM) and eigenvector algorithm (EVA),26 application in ultrasonic inspection of composite materials and pipes.13

The MED method is a type of blind deconvolution in which only the system’s input is desired while both the system and the system’s input are not known. MED, which is designed to reduce the spread of impulse response frequencies to obtain signals closer to the original impulses that gave rise to them, searches for an optimum set of filter coefficients to minimum the entropy. Therefore the filtered signal enhances the structured fault information in the signal.

The OFM is applied in the design of MED filter by Lee.26 The aim is to find an optimal finite impulse response (FIR) filter g(l) to let the filtered signal y(k) much closer to the original signal x(k), where a certain time delay τ or an overall scale factor β is allowed. Shown in equation (3) is z(l) which is the observed signal by sensors, and L which is the length of the optimal FIR filter. (3)y(k)=∑k=1Lg(l)z(k-l)≈βx(k-τ)
According to references, the objective function is shown as the following (4)O4(g(l))=∑k=1Ny4(k)/[∑k=1Ny2(k)]2
Combining with equation (3), one gets (5)[∑k=1Ny2(k)/∑k=1Ny4(k)]∑k=1Ny3(k)z(k-l)︸b =∑P=1Lg(p)︸g∑k=1Nz(k-i)z(k-P)︸A

Equation (5) can be written in the matrix form b=gA, where b represents cross-relationship of input and output signal of the FIR filter; A is a Toeplitz autocorrelation matrix of the observed signal by sensors, and g is the column vector of the required FIR filter coefficients.

The algorithm can be realized as the following:
Compute the Toeplitz autocorrelation matrix A, and assume the initial optimal FIR filter coefficients g(0).
Compute the output signal y(k) using the input signal z(l) and the optimal FIR filter coefficients g(k) according to equation (3), where k means kth iteration.
Compute the left side of the equation (5)b(k+1), and solve the new optimal FIR filter coefficients g(k+1)=A-1b(k+1).
Compute the error criterion (6){E(err)=E[(g(k)-μgk-1)/μgk-1]μ=(E(gk-1))2/(E(gk)2)1/2
If the E(err)>tolerance, then go to step 2 with the new the optimal FIR filter coefficients g(k+1); otherwise stop the process.
According to Endo’s research on the effectiveness of MED filter length and setting of the tolerance, we set the MED filter length as L = 40, tolerance=0.01.14

sec.title: Envelop spectrum analysis
sec.p: Envelop spectrum analysis based on Hilbert transform has been widely used in bearing fault diagnosis.18 It can be used to separate modulating signal from the carrier signal, which typically contains information that indicates the faults. As for rolling element bearing, some of the characteristic frequencies, which can be used for bearing fault diagnosis, will appear in the separated information. The envelop signal E(t) of the original input s(t) can be obtained as the following (7){E(t)=|z(t)|=|s(t)+jh(t)|=s2(t)+h2(t)h(t)=1π∫-∞∞s(τ)t-τdτ=1πt*s(t) where h(t) is the Hilbert transform of s(t), z(t) is the complex signal which is made up of two parts. Then the envelop spectrum analysis can be obtained by performing the FFT of the envelop signal E(t).

sec.title: Simulation analysis validation
sec.p: In order to validate the proposed method, the bearing signal with inner defect is simulated by equation (2). The parameters of the simulated signal are listed as follows: The sampling frequency fs is 25.6 kHz, the natural frequency fn is 4 kHz, the shaft rotating frequency fr is 10 Hz, and the inner race frequency fi is 57 Hz. The τk is 0.005, the SNR = −12 dB, and the data length of signal is 20,480.

Figure 3(a1) shows the raw signal and Figure 3(a2) displays the filtered time waveform, where the filter is designed by MED method. Figure 3(b1) and (b2) shows the PSD estimation of (a1) and (a2), respectively. It is clear that the PSD estimation under strong noise such as when the SNR = −12 dB could not find the characteristic frequencies, so it failed to detect the weak fault. While after the enhancement of MED filter, the natural frequency can be detected easily with PSD estimation, which can be used in condition monitoring. The envelop spectrum of (a1) is shown in Figure 3(c1), it is confounded in finding the fault frequency components. While in Figure 3(c2), it is obvious that there are some harmonic frequencies besides the characteristic frequency fi and rotating frequency fr. The simulation demonstrates the feasibility and validity of utilizing the MED in the weak fault diagnosis and condition monitoring of rolling element bearing. Figure 3.
Simulated bearing inner race defect with SNR = −12 dB: (a) time waveform, (b) PSD estimation, (c) envelop spectrum analysis.
SNR: signal noise ratio; PSD: power spectral density.

sec.title: Experiment results validation
sec.p: On the above simulation, the feasibility and validity of utilizing the MED in the fault diagnosis and condition monitoring under strong additive stationary noise is demonstrated. In this section, two cases are considered to investigate the effectiveness of the proposed method. Case I focuses on the early incipient fault, so an accelerated life test of rolling bearing was performed to collect data over the entire lifetime (normal fault failure). In application, bearings are often associated with other equipment such as gears, and the fault information is corrupted by strong background noise (vibration of gear and so on). So in case II, a single-stage gearbox test with one inner race fault bearing is performed to collect experimental data.

sec.title: Case I: Incipient fault detect and diagnosis
sec.p: In the previous experiments, electrical discharge machining was widely used to obtain artificial defects of rolling element bearings with different sizes at different positions. However, this cannot simulate the performance degradation and the real fault state in practice. Nevertheless, it is not feasible to collect whole life vibration date (normal fault failure) from normal operations as the process may take a huge amount of time. Therefore, an accelerated life test of rolling bearing was performed to collect vibration data over the entire lifetime and the early incipient data was used to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

sec.title: Experiment rig
sec.p:
The accelerated bearing life test was performed in Hangzhou Bearing Test & Research Center (HBRC). It simultaneously hosted four rolling element bearing on one shaft driven by an AC motor and coupled by rubber belts. For improved test efficiency, a new bearing was installed if one failed. The complete experiment is shown in Figure 4. The test rolling element bearing type was 6307 with its corresponding parameters and operating conditions shown in Table 1; oil lubrication was adopted. Five characteristic frequencies are shown in Table 2. The data acquisition system included three acceleration sensors (the installation sketch map is shown in Figure 5), four thermocouples that record the outer race temperature of each bearing, one anti-aliasing filter instrument, and the DAQCard-6023 E data acquisition card. The software was programmed by the National Instruments Labview. One group of data was collected every minute with the data sampling rate of 25.6 kHz, and the length of data was 20,480 points. Figure 4.
Experiment equipment of case I.
Figure 5.
Sketch of acceleration sensors installation.
Table 1.
Rolling element bearing parameters and operation condition.
Type Ball number Ball diameter (mm) Pitch diameter (mm) Contact angle Motor speed (r/min) Load (kN)
6307 8 13.494 58.5 0 3000 12.744
Table 2.
Characteristic frequencies of rolling element bearing 6307 (Hz).
fr fc fb fi fo
50 19 102 246 153

sec.title: Results and analysis
sec.p:
One of the failure bearing is studied in this article, its collected data group is 1962. The RMS of the entire life, which is a commonly used index to characterize a signal’s intensity, is shown in Figure 6. Previous 900 groups were cancelled because the RMS value almost remained the same when the bearing was normal, and the localization enlargement around the abrupt crease (group 1878) is shown in Figure 7. There must have been severe faults in the bearing when the RMS increases abruptly at group 1878. In order to investigate the feasibility and validity of the proposed method, the data group earlier than the group 1878 is studied in the article. And we found that the proposed method is effective in diagnosing fault even at the data group 1871, which is 7 min earlier than the RMS can reflect while the entire life takes 1962 min. This is considered to be significant in condition monitoring and early incipient fault diagnosis. The bearing after the accelerate life test, which is confirmed an inner race fault, is shown in Figure 8. Figure 6.
RMS of the entire life.
Figure 7.
RMS localization enlargement around group 1878.
Figure 8.
Bearing failure after accelerated life test.

The time waveform of group 1871 before and after MED filter is shown in Figure 9. And many obvious periodic impulses are clearly shown in Figure 9(b), which may be caused by the impact of two contact surfaces. Figure 10 is the PSD estimation of signal. The PSD estimation in bearing condition monitoring is illustrated in section ‘Power spectrum density estimation.’ The energy of the original signal is mainly concentrated in the area lower than 2 kHz, which is more likely to indicate that the bearing is normal. But after the MED filter, the energy between 5 and 7 kHz are the main part. This may be caused by bearing early incipient fault with resonances frequency of the structure ranging between 5 and 7 kHz. Figure 9.
Time waveform of the signal of group 1871: (a) original signal, and (b) filtered signal with MED.
MED: minimum entropy deconvolution.
Figure 10.
PSD estimation of the signal of group 1871: (a) original signal, and (b) filtered signal with MED.
PED: power spectral density; MED: minimum entropy deconvolution.

In order to obtain clear fault information, further analysis is adopted. The envelop spectrum analysis before and after the MED filter is shown in Figure 11. The fault information can hardly be obtained from the original signal. While in Figure 11(b), it can be seen that the characteristic frequencies are both fi and its harmonics modulated by fr, which implies the occurrence of inner race fault. Figure 11.
Envelop spectrum analysis of the signal of group 1871: (a) original signal, and (b) filtered signal with MED.
MED: minimum entropy deconvolution.

The data group 1870, whose RMS is almost the same with data group 1871, is used as comparison. Figure 12 is the PSD estimation of group 1870. The PSD estimation of the original signal is almost the same with the case of group 1871 with less energy in the area larger than 2 kHz, but it is not obvious. The PSD estimation after MED filter differs greatly with Figure 10(b), and the energy is more concentrated than the original signal shown in Figure 12(a). The filtered signal indicates that the bearing is without any defect. This experiment demonstrates that the MED technique can detect or diagnose the early incipient fault even in the case where the original signal cannot detect or diagnose any defects. This is of great significance in bearing condition monitoring and fault diagnosis. Figure 12.
PSD estimation of the signal of group 1870: (a) original signal, and (b) filtered signal with MED.
PSD: power spectral density; MED: minimum entropy deconvolution.

sec.title: Case II: Fault detect and diagnosis under strong noise
sec.p: From the previous analysis, MED is found to have excellent ability in bearing early incipient fault diagnosis and condition monitoring. And in application, fault diagnosis may be very difficult because the bearings are often associated with other equipment such as gears, and the fault information is corrupted by strong background noise. Therefore, a single-stage gearbox test with one inner race fault bearing is performed to collect experimental data.

sec.title: Experiment rig
sec.p:
The test rig, which is shown in Figure 13, consists of a parallel shaft spur gear pair, operating with a ratio of 39:28. The test rolling element bearing type is 6203 with its corresponding parameters and operating condition shown in Table 3. Five characteristic frequencies are shown in Table 4. Inner race fault was processed by EDM with defect length, width and depth to be 1.0 mm, 4 mm and 0.5 mm, respectively. The picture of test bearing is shown in Figure 14. The data was collected using an accelerometer (BK 4507B) positioned on the top of the gearbox casing right above the defective bearing with NI 9234. Five seconds data was collected with sampling rate of 51.2 kHz, and the input shaft speed was set to 9.6 Hz (576 r/min) while the load was 2 N m. Figure 13.
Experiment equipment of case II.
Figure 14.
Testing bearing with inner race defect.
Table 3.
Rolling element bearing parameters and operation condition.
Type Ball number Ball diameter (mm) Pitch diameter (mm) Contact angle Motor speed (r/min) Load (N m)
6203 8 6.747 28.5 0 600 2.0
Table 4.
Characteristic frequencies of rolling element bearing 6203 (Hz).
fr fc fb fi fo
9.6 2.67 38.28 47.5 29.3

sec.title: Results and analysis
sec.p:
The time waveforms of the signal before and after MED filter are shown in Figure 15, and the PSD estimation is shown in Figure 16. The energy distribution of gearbox is much more complicated than the bearing, this is obvious in Figure 16(a). The case of gear and bearing interactions was researched by Sawalhi and Randall,27,28 and there was an increase in energy of around 15 kHz when a defect was introduced. As shown in Figure 16(b), the energy of around 15 kHz is more concentrated. This was consistent with the Sawalhi’s research. Envelop spectrum analysis of the signal before and after MED filter are shown in Figure 17(a) and (b), respectively. It can be seen that there are many frequency components, such as 6.8 Hz (the output shaft frequency), 9.6 Hz (the input shaft frequency), 40.4 Hz, 47.5 Hz, 59 Hz, and 262.8 Hz (gear mesh frequency) in Figure 17(a). It is confounded in finding the fault frequency components. While in Figure 17(b), it is obvious that there are some harmonic frequencies besides the characteristic frequency fi and rotating frequency fr. The experiment demonstrates the feasibility and validity of utilizing the MED in the bearing fault detect and diagnosis even when the fault information is corrupted by strong background noise due to other equipments. Figure 15.
Time waveform of the signal: (a) original signal, and (b) filtered signal with MED.
MED: minimum entropy deconvolution.
Figure 16.
PSD estimation of the signal: (a) original signal, and (b) filtered signal with MED.
PSD: power spectral density; MED: minimum entropy deconvolution.
Figure 17.
Envelop spectrum analysis of the signal: (a) original signal, and (b) filtered signal with MED.
MED: minimum entropy deconvolution.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this article, a method based on MED combined with envelop analysis is applied to the weak fault diagnosis of rolling element bearing. An optimal set of filter coefficients can be got from MED, which may maximize the fault impulse. Both simulation and experiments are achieved to show that it has a good ability in fault diagnosis. Moreover, it can detect fault 7 min earlier than what RMS can reflect. As for condition monitoring, the 7 min fault detection in advance is very important to the safe running of the equipment. In experiment II, a single-stage gearbox test with one inner race fault bearing is performed to acquire experimental data. Bearing fault manifest themselves by their interaction with meshing gears, in which envelop analysis fails to detect the fault due to the strong background noise. By applying the proposed method, an optimal FIR filter coefficients is generated, which can extract the fault signal efficiently. This is considered to be significant in condition monitoring and fault diagnosis when a strong background noise exists.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundations of China (Grant Nos. 51035007, 51175329 and 51105243).

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors acknowledge the support provided by Hangzhou Bearing Test & Research Center (HBRC) in carrying out the experiment. The authors would also like to appreciate the work of editors and reviewers.
